bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, July 29, 1947

div1.p: Kean feels Moran is too contentious about the Cuban medical profession taking all the credit for the yellow fever discovery. Kean tells Hench the advice he gave Moran about how to approach his autobiography, or memoirs, without angering the Cubans.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, July 29, 1947
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
29 July '47
My dear Col. Hench
div1.p:
I received about a week ago a
letter from Moran inclosing a type
written copy of the first two or three pages
of his memoirs. There was really no
biographical material in it, but it was
a fierce attack on the Cuban medical
profession for their partisan spirit in the
matter of the respective merits of Findlay
and Reed - Altho. he maintains that
there should be a fair division of the credit,
he does not mention that American doctors
are not free from blame in their failure
to give anysufficient credit to Findlay - while
what he says of the Havana doctors is quite
true. Moran ignores the old french proverb:
2
Toutes les vérités ne sont pas bonnes à dire-
His tone is too contentions to convert any one
and would do more harm than good.

I pointed out to him the difference in meaning
between memoir and memoirs. In the Singular
it means an essay or treatise about one subject,
whereas when one writes his memoirs the plural
implies something biographical and longer.
I told him that I hoped he would give us in a
simple style, which is always the best, the story
of his life; where he was born and the circum-
stances of his bringing up, and his army service-
Then when he got to the yellow fever episode
he could describe that and his connection
with it. Then he could naturally comment
on the pity that a partisan spirit has arisen
to warp the facts of medical history and substitute
national prejudices to replace the judicial and
scientific attitude of mind. I suggested that
he should state the facts and let the reader
draw his own conclusions. Entre nous I fear
3
that we wont get much out of him. He
hasn't the judicial type of mind. I told him
that one fact should be stated as regards the
work of the Reed Board: that Findlay had
for ten years been announcing his theory
with tongue and pen in both Spanish and
English and had made only one convert, his
disciple Delgado. Yet within a month after
he had made his report of the Camp Lazear
experiments the Findlay theory had been
accepted by the medical profession of
Havana and generally in the U.S.
If the Cubans are told that it is enough,
without any further discussion.

I know that you are interested in
Moran's memoirs whether with or
without the S, as I am too, but I think
the time has not yet come to look
around for a publisher.
